metadata.subject: Reading
metadata.description: CCSS-aligned reading comprehension assessment with literary and informational texts

questions.text: How did Ma Liang get the magic paintbrush?

choices: He bought it at a store
An old man gave it to him in a dream
He found it on the ground
The emperor gave it to him
questionOptions.correctAnswer: An old man gave it to him in a dream

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Long ago in China, there lived a poor boy named Ma Liang. He loved to draw but had no brush. One night, an old man appeared in his dream and gave him a magic paintbrush. "Use it wisely," the man said. When Ma Liang woke up, the brush was real! Whatever he painted came to life. He painted food for hungry people and tools for farmers. The greedy emperor heard about the brush. He wanted it for himself. But Ma Liang was clever. He used the brush to help people escape from the emperor. The paintbrush only worked for those with kind hearts.
questions.explanation: The text states an old man appeared in his dream and gave him the brush.

questions.text: What is the central message of this story?

choices: Use your gifts to help others
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Use your gifts to help others

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows Ma Liang using his gift to help people.

questions.text: How did Ma Liang respond when the emperor wanted his brush?

choices: He cleverly used it to help people escape
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He cleverly used it to help people escape

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'He used the brush to help people escape from the emperor.'

questions.text: From whose point of view is this story told?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: A narrator outside the story

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story is told by a third-person narrator.

questions.text: What does 'Use it wisely' mean in this story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Use it carefully and for good purposes

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The old man wants Ma Liang to use the gift responsibly to help others.

questions.text: What makes leaves green?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Chlorophyll

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I1: Why Do Leaves Change Color?
questions.passageText: In autumn, leaves change from green to beautiful colors like red, orange, and yellow. But why does this happen? Leaves are green because of chlorophyll. Chlorophyll helps plants make food from sunlight. In fall, there is less sunlight. The chlorophyll breaks down and goes away. Without the green chlorophyll, we can see other colors that were hiding in the leaves all along. Yellow and orange colors were always there. Red colors are made when sugars get trapped in the leaves. Different trees make different colors. Oak trees turn red and brown. Maple trees can be bright orange or red. Aspen trees turn golden yellow. The shorter days and cooler nights of autumn create this colorful show.
questions.explanation: The text states 'Leaves are green because of chlorophyll.'

questions.text: What is the main topic of this text?

choices: Why leaves change color in fall
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Why leaves change color in fall

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I1: Why Do Leaves Change Color?
questions.explanation: The main topic is explaining why leaves change color.

questions.text: What does 'breaks down' mean in this text?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Stops working and disappears

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I1: Why Do Leaves Change Color?
questions.explanation: In this context, it means the chlorophyll stops working and goes away.

questions.text: What happens to cause red colors in leaves?

choices: Sugars get trapped in the leaves
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Sugars get trapped in the leaves

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I1: Why Do Leaves Change Color?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Red colors are made when sugars get trapped in the leaves.'

questions.text: How is this text organized?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Cause and effect

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I1: Why Do Leaves Change Color?
questions.explanation: The text explains the causes that lead to leaves changing color.

questions.text: What problem did the crow face?

choices: He was lost in the desert
He could see water but could not reach it
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He could see water but could not reach it

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L2: The Crow and the Pitcher
questions.passageText: A thirsty crow flew over the hot desert. He had not had a drink in days. At last, he spotted a pitcher on the ground. He flew down and looked inside. There was water at the bottom! But when the crow put his beak in, he could not reach the water. The pitcher was too deep. The crow thought and thought. Then he had an idea. He picked up a small stone and dropped it in the pitcher. The water rose a tiny bit. He dropped in another stone, and another. Each stone made the water rise higher. Finally, the water was high enough. The crow drank until he was no longer thirsty. His clever thinking had saved his life.
questions.explanation: The crow could not reach the water at the bottom of the deep pitcher.

questions.text: What lesson does this fable teach?

choices: Crows are smarter than other birds
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Clever thinking can solve problems

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L2: The Crow and the Pitcher
questions.explanation: The fable teaches that using your mind can help solve difficult problems.

questions.text: How does the story build to the solution?

choices: The crow tries one stone, then keeps adding more
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The crow tries one stone, then keeps adding more

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L2: The Crow and the Pitcher
questions.explanation: The story shows the crow's repeated action of adding stones until he succeeds.

questions.text: What made the water rise in the pitcher?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The crow dropped stones in

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L2: The Crow and the Pitcher
questions.explanation: The text says he dropped stones in and 'Each stone made the water rise higher.'

questions.text: What does 'clever thinking' mean in this story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Using your brain to find a smart solution

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L2: The Crow and the Pitcher
questions.explanation: The crow used his intelligence to solve the problem of reaching the water.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Butterflies change through four stages

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I2: The Life of a Butterfly
questions.passageText: Butterflies go through an amazing change called metamorphosis. It happens in four stages. First, a butterfly lays tiny eggs on a leaf. After a few days, a caterpillar hatches from each egg. The caterpillar is very hungry. It eats and eats leaves. It grows bigger and bigger. Next comes the chrysalis stage. The caterpillar makes a hard shell around itself. Inside this shell, something magical happens. The caterpillar's body completely changes. Finally, a butterfly emerges. It has colorful wings and can fly. The whole process takes about one month. The butterfly that comes out looks nothing like the caterpillar that went in!
questions.explanation: The main idea is the four-stage metamorphosis of butterflies.

questions.text: What does 'emerges' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Comes out

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I2: The Life of a Butterfly
questions.explanation: Emerges means comes out of the chrysalis.

questions.text: How is this text organized?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: In the order things happen (sequence)

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I2: The Life of a Butterfly
questions.explanation: The text follows the sequence of butterfly development.

questions.text: What happens during the chrysalis stage?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The caterpillar's body completely changes

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I2: The Life of a Butterfly
questions.explanation: The text states that inside the chrysalis, the body 'completely changes.'

questions.text: How long does the metamorphosis process take?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: About one month

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I2: The Life of a Butterfly
questions.explanation: The text says 'The whole process takes about one month.'

questions.text: Where did the tamale recipe come from?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Abuela's grandmother

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Every Sunday, Rosa visited her abuela's house. Abuela always made tamales. Rosa watched carefully as Abuela spread masa on corn husks. "This recipe is from my grandmother," Abuela said. "Now I teach you." Rosa felt proud. She spread the masa just like Abuela showed her. It was harder than it looked! Some masa went on her nose. Abuela laughed warmly. "Practice makes perfect, mija." They filled the tamales with chicken and wrapped them tight. As they steamed, the kitchen filled with delicious smells. Rosa thought about how this recipe traveled through her family for generations. Someday, she would teach her own children. The tamales were more than food—they were love wrapped in corn husks.
questions.explanation: The text says 'This recipe is from my grandmother.'

questions.text: What is the theme of this story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Family traditions connect generations

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story emphasizes how recipes and traditions pass through generations.

questions.text: How did Rosa feel about learning to make tamales?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Proud

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Rosa felt proud.'

questions.text: What does 'mija' most likely mean?

choices: A term of endearment for a girl
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A term of endearment for a girl

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Mija is a Spanish term of endearment meaning 'my daughter.'

questions.text: Why does the author say tamales were 'love wrapped in corn husks'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Because making tamales together showed the family's love for each other
acceptableAnswers: the family shares love through cooking

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The tamales represent the love and tradition shared between family members.

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?

choices: How hurricanes form and why they're dangerous
questionOptions.correctAnswer: How hurricanes form and why they're dangerous

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Hurricanes are powerful storms that form over warm ocean water. They can be very dangerous. A hurricane starts when warm, moist air rises from the ocean. As this air goes up, it leaves an area of low pressure below. More air rushes in to fill the space, and this air also rises. This pattern makes the air spin. If conditions are right, the storm gets stronger and becomes a hurricane. Hurricanes have strong winds that spin around a center called the eye. The eye is surprisingly calm. Around the eye, winds can blow faster than 157 miles per hour! Hurricanes bring heavy rain and can cause floods. Scientists use satellites and planes to track hurricanes. This helps people know when to stay safe or leave their homes.
questions.explanation: The main topic is explaining hurricanes.

questions.text: What does 'track' mean in this text?

choices: Follow and observe the movement of
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Follow and observe the movement of

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: To track hurricanes means to follow and observe where they go.

questions.text: What is the eye of a hurricane?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The calm center

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The eye is surprisingly calm.'

questions.text: Why do scientists track hurricanes?

choices: To help people know when to stay safe
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To help people know when to stay safe

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'This helps people know when to stay safe or leave their homes.'

questions.text: What causes the air to spin in a hurricane?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Warm air rises, creating low pressure, and more air rushes in and rises, making it spin

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains this cycle of rising air that creates spinning motion.

questions.text: What is the lesson of this story?

choices: Honesty is the most important quality
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Honesty is the most important quality

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: In ancient China, an emperor needed to choose the next ruler. He gave each child a seed. "Return in one year with what you have grown," he said. Jun planted his seed carefully. He watered it every day. He made sure it had sunlight. But nothing grew. He tried different soil. Still nothing. A year passed, and Jun had only an empty pot. He was ashamed, but his mother said, "You must go. Tell the truth." At the palace, Jun saw children with beautiful flowers. The emperor walked past them without smiling. Then he saw Jun's empty pot. "Ah!" The emperor smiled. "I boiled all the seeds. None could grow. You are the only honest one." Jun became the next emperor because he told the truth.
questions.explanation: The story teaches that honesty is rewarded, even when it's difficult.

questions.text: Why did the other children have beautiful flowers?

choices: They must have gotten different seeds
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They must have gotten different seeds

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Since the emperor boiled all seeds, the other children must have cheated with different seeds.

questions.text: Why did the emperor smile when he saw Jun's empty pot?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He knew Jun was honest

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The emperor was looking for someone honest, and Jun proved his honesty.

questions.text: How does the author want readers to feel about Jun?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Proud of his honesty

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author shows Jun's honesty being rewarded, making readers feel proud of him.

questions.text: How did Jun feel about bringing an empty pot? How did his feelings change?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He felt ashamed at first but was rewarded for being honest

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Jun went from feeling ashamed to being chosen as the next emperor.

questions.text: What reasons does the author give for why bats are helpful?

choices: They eat insects, spread seeds, and pollinate flowers
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They eat insects, spread seeds, and pollinate flowers

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I4: Bats: Helpers of the Night
questions.passageText: Many people are afraid of bats, but bats are actually very helpful. Bats are mammals, like dogs and cats. They are the only mammals that can truly fly. Most bats are nocturnal, meaning they are active at night. Bats help us in many ways. Some bats eat insects. A single bat can eat over 1,000 mosquitoes in one night! This helps control bug populations. Other bats eat fruit and spread seeds. This helps new plants grow in forests. Some bats drink nectar from flowers and spread pollen, just like bees. Without bats, many plants could not make seeds. Bats use echolocation to find food in the dark. They make sounds that bounce off objects and return to their ears. This tells them where things are. Bats are important members of our ecosystems.
questions.explanation: The text gives these three ways bats help: eating insects, spreading seeds, and spreading pollen.

questions.text: What does 'nocturnal' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Active at night

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I4: Bats: Helpers of the Night
questions.explanation: The text says 'nocturnal, meaning they are active at night.'

questions.text: What is the author's purpose for writing this text?

choices: To explain how bats find food
To change how people think about bats
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To change how people think about bats

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I4: Bats: Helpers of the Night
questions.explanation: The author wants to change people's fear of bats by showing how helpful they are.

questions.text: How do bats find food in the dark?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: They use echolocation

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I4: Bats: Helpers of the Night
questions.explanation: The text says 'Bats use echolocation to find food in the dark.'

questions.text: What are two facts that support the idea that bats are helpful?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: They eat 1,000+ mosquitoes per night; they spread seeds; they pollinate flowers
acceptableAnswers: control bugs and help plants grow

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-I4: Bats: Helpers of the Night
questions.explanation: The text provides several facts showing bats' benefits.

questions.text: How did Mei feel at the beginning of the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Nervous

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Mei was nervous. Tomorrow was the school singing competition. She had practiced her song many times, but her voice shook when she was scared. That night, her older brother Chen found her pacing in her room. "What's wrong?" he asked. Mei explained her fear. Chen nodded. "I get scared too," he said. "But I imagine I'm singing just for one person I love. Focus on that feeling, not the crowd." The next day, Mei walked onto the stage. Her hands were sweaty. She saw hundreds of faces. Then she spotted her family in the front row. She imagined singing just for them. Her voice started shaky, but it grew stronger. By the end, she was smiling. She didn't win first place, but she finished. That felt like the biggest victory of all.
questions.explanation: The text opens with 'Mei was nervous.'

questions.text: What advice did Chen give Mei?

choices: Imagine singing for one person you love
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Imagine singing for one person you love

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Chen said 'I imagine I'm singing just for one person I love.'

questions.text: What is the theme of this story?

choices: Overcoming fear is a personal victory
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Overcoming fear is a personal victory

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows that finishing despite fear was Mei's 'biggest victory.'

questions.text: How does the story's structure show Mei's growth?

choices: It starts with her winning and ends with her practicing
It starts with her fear and ends with her feeling successful
It compares her to other singers
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It starts with her fear and ends with her feeling successful

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story moves from Mei's nervousness to her feeling victorious.

questions.text: How did Mei change from the beginning to the end of the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: She went from being scared and shaky to feeling confident and successful

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Mei overcame her fear and felt proud of herself.

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?

choices: How different types of bridges work
questionOptions.correctAnswer: How different types of bridges work

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Bridges help us cross rivers, valleys, and roads. But how do they stay up? All bridges must handle two forces: compression and tension. Compression is a pushing force that squeezes things together. Tension is a pulling force that stretches things. Different bridges handle these forces in different ways. Beam bridges are the simplest. A flat surface rests on supports at each end. The supports handle the weight by pushing down. Arch bridges curve upward. The curved shape pushes forces outward to the ground. Arch bridges have been built for thousands of years. Suspension bridges hang from cables attached to tall towers. The cables are in tension—they are being pulled. The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco is a famous suspension bridge. Engineers choose which type of bridge to build based on what needs to be crossed.
questions.explanation: The main topic is explaining how different bridge types handle forces.

questions.text: What is compression?

choices: A pushing force that squeezes things
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A pushing force that squeezes things

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Compression is a pushing force that squeezes things together.'

questions.text: How is this text organized?

choices: By comparing different types of bridges
questionOptions.correctAnswer: By comparing different types of bridges

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text compares beam, arch, and suspension bridges.

questions.text: What kind of bridge is the Golden Gate Bridge?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Suspension bridge

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says it 'is a famous suspension bridge.'

questions.text: How is an arch bridge different from a beam bridge?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: An arch bridge curves upward and pushes forces outward; a beam bridge is flat and rests on supports
acceptableAnswers: arch pushes outward, beam pushes down

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text describes these different shapes and how they handle weight differently.

questions.text: What is the lesson of this fable?

choices: Slow and steady wins the race
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Slow and steady wins the race

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L6: The Rabbit and the Turtle Race
questions.passageText: Rabbit was the fastest animal in the forest. He bragged every day. "No one can beat me!" Turtle was tired of his bragging. "I will race you," Turtle said. Rabbit laughed. "You? That's the funniest thing I've heard!" They agreed to race to the big oak tree. When the race started, Rabbit zoomed ahead. He ran so fast that Turtle disappeared behind him. "I have plenty of time," Rabbit thought. He stopped to eat some clover. Then he felt sleepy and took a nap under a tree. Meanwhile, Turtle kept walking. Step by step. Slow but steady. When Rabbit woke up, he saw Turtle near the finish line! Rabbit ran as fast as he could, but it was too late. Turtle crossed the finish line first. "Slow and steady wins the race," Turtle said with a smile.
questions.explanation: The turtle states the lesson at the end: 'Slow and steady wins the race.'

questions.text: Why did Rabbit lose the race?

choices: He stopped to eat and take a nap
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He stopped to eat and take a nap

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L6: The Rabbit and the Turtle Race
questions.explanation: Rabbit lost because he was overconfident and wasted time.

questions.text: How does the author make Rabbit look foolish?

choices: By showing how he brags and then loses
By having other animals laugh at him
questionOptions.correctAnswer: By showing how he brags and then loses

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L6: The Rabbit and the Turtle Race
questions.explanation: The author shows Rabbit's bragging followed by his loss to teach a lesson.

questions.text: What did Rabbit do while Turtle kept walking?

choices: Ate clover and took a nap
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Ate clover and took a nap

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L6: The Rabbit and the Turtle Race
questions.explanation: The text says Rabbit 'stopped to eat some clover' and 'took a nap.'

questions.text: What does 'slow and steady' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Going at a careful, consistent pace without stopping
acceptableAnswers: keep going at a steady pace

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passage: G2-L6: The Rabbit and the Turtle Race
questions.explanation: It means continuing at a regular pace without giving up or getting distracted.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: George Washington Carver helped farmers with his inventions
questionOptions.correctAnswer: George Washington Carver helped farmers with his inventions

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: George Washington Carver was an amazing scientist who helped farmers. He was born into slavery around 1864. After slavery ended, he worked hard to get an education. He became the first Black student at his college. Later, he became a famous professor. Carver saw that many Southern farmers were struggling. They had planted cotton for so many years that the soil was worn out. Carver found a solution: peanuts! Peanut plants put nutrients back into the soil. But there was a problem. Farmers didn't want to grow peanuts because no one would buy them. So Carver invented over 300 uses for peanuts—including dyes, plastics, and even gasoline! He also found uses for sweet potatoes and pecans. Thanks to Carver, farmers could make money and heal their land at the same time.
questions.explanation: The main idea is how Carver used science to help struggling farmers.

questions.text: What problem did Carver solve?

choices: The soil was worn out from growing cotton
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The soil was worn out from growing cotton

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Carver solved the problem of worn-out soil caused by cotton farming.

questions.text: How many uses did Carver find for peanuts?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Over 300

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Carver invented over 300 uses for peanuts.'

questions.text: Why did Carver need to find uses for peanuts?

choices: Farmers wouldn't grow them if no one would buy them
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Farmers wouldn't grow them if no one would buy them

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains 'Farmers didn't want to grow peanuts because no one would buy them.'

questions.text: What does the author want readers to understand about George Washington Carver?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He was a brilliant scientist who overcame challenges and helped many people
acceptableAnswers: he overcame obstacles and invented many things

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author presents Carver as someone who used his intelligence to solve real problems.

questions.text: Where did Grandfather make the kite?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: In Japan

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Kai and his grandfather stood in the field on a windy spring day. Grandfather held a beautiful kite shaped like a dragon. "I made this kite in Japan when I was your age," Grandfather said. The dragon had golden scales and long ribbons for a tail. Kai was excited but also worried. "What if it breaks?" he asked. Grandfather smiled. "Then we fix it together. That's part of loving something." He showed Kai how to hold the string and feel the wind. At first, the kite dipped and dove. But Kai learned to pull and release at the right times. Soon the dragon soared high above them. Its ribbons danced against the blue sky. "You're a natural," Grandfather said proudly. Kai knew this wasn't just about flying a kite. It was about learning from someone who loved him.
questions.explanation: The text says 'I made this kite in Japan when I was your age.'

questions.text: What is the deeper message of this story?

choices: Learning from loved ones is special
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Learning from loved ones is special

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story is about the bond between Kai and his grandfather, not just kite flying.

questions.text: How did Kai feel about the kite at first?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Excited but worried

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Kai was excited but also worried.'

questions.text: What does 'You're a natural' mean?

choices: You're doing something well without much practice
questionOptions.correctAnswer: You're doing something well without much practice

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: It means Kai learned quickly and did well naturally.

questions.text: Why does the author include Grandfather's words 'Then we fix it together'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: To show that Grandfather cares about teaching Kai and spending time with him, not just the kite
acceptableAnswers: relationship matters more than the kite

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: These words reveal that the relationship matters more than the object.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: Earthquakes happen when tectonic plates move
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Earthquakes happen when tectonic plates move

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: The ground beneath our feet might seem solid and still, but Earth's surface is actually always moving. The outer layer of Earth is made of huge pieces called tectonic plates. These plates float on hot, melted rock below. The plates move very slowly—about as fast as your fingernails grow. Sometimes plates push against each other. They can get stuck. Pressure builds up. When the plates suddenly slip and move, an earthquake happens! The place underground where the plates slip is called the focus. The spot directly above it on the surface is called the epicenter. The epicenter usually has the strongest shaking. Scientists use machines called seismographs to measure earthquakes. The strength is measured on a scale. Small earthquakes happen every day around the world. Most are so small that people don't feel them. Large earthquakes can cause buildings to fall and create cracks in the ground.
questions.explanation: The main idea is explaining what causes earthquakes.

questions.text: What is the 'epicenter'?

choices: The place underground where plates slip
The spot on the surface directly above where plates slip
The edge of a tectonic plate
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The spot on the surface directly above where plates slip

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The spot directly above it on the surface is called the epicenter.'

questions.text: What causes an earthquake?

choices: Plates suddenly slipping after building pressure
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Plates suddenly slipping after building pressure

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains that plates get stuck, pressure builds, and 'when the plates suddenly slip and move, an earthquake happens.'

questions.text: How does the author explain how fast plates move?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: By comparing to fingernail growth

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author says plates move 'about as fast as your fingernails grow.'

questions.text: How do scientists measure earthquakes?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: They use machines called seismographs

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text states 'Scientists use machines called seismographs to measure earthquakes.'

questions.text: How did Carlos feel about Mrs. Kim at the beginning?

choices: He had never spoken to her
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He had never spoken to her

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: On one side of the wall lived Carlos. On the other side lived Mrs. Kim. Carlos had never spoken to her. His ball sometimes flew over the wall into her garden. She always threw it back. One day, Carlos noticed a hole in the wall. Through it, he saw the most beautiful garden—flowers of every color, vegetables in neat rows, and a small pond. "Hello," said a voice. It was Mrs. Kim, kneeling by her tomatoes. Carlos froze. "I've seen you watching," she said kindly. "Would you like to see the garden?" Carlos walked around the wall and through her gate. Mrs. Kim showed him everything. She even let him pick a ripe tomato. "Gardens need friends," she said. "Would you help me sometimes?" Carlos nodded eagerly. The wall was still there, but it didn't seem so tall anymore.
questions.explanation: The text says 'Carlos had never spoken to her.'

questions.text: What is the theme of this story?

choices: Balls should stay in your yard
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Connection with others is valuable

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows how Carlos and Mrs. Kim formed a connection that made the wall seem less important.

questions.text: What did Carlos see through the hole in the wall?

choices: A beautiful garden with flowers, vegetables, and a pond
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A beautiful garden with flowers, vegetables, and a pond

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text describes 'the most beautiful garden—flowers of every color, vegetables in neat rows, and a small pond.'

questions.text: What does the author mean by 'the wall didn't seem so tall anymore'?

Mrs. Kim removed part of the wall
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Their friendship made the barrier between them feel smaller

questions.text: How did the relationship between Carlos and Mrs. Kim change?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: They went from strangers to friends who would help each other in the garden

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: Octopuses are amazing animals with many special abilities
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Octopuses are amazing animals with many special abilities

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: The octopus is one of the most incredible animals in the ocean. It has eight arms, no bones, and three hearts! Octopuses are very intelligent. Scientists have watched them solve puzzles and open jars to get food. They can even recognize different people! One of the octopus's most amazing abilities is camouflage. It can change its color and texture in less than a second. It does this to hide from predators or sneak up on prey. If camouflage doesn't work, the octopus has another trick. It can squirt ink to confuse enemies. The ink creates a dark cloud that lets the octopus escape. An octopus can also squeeze through incredibly tiny spaces. Because it has no bones, it can fit through any hole larger than its beak. An octopus the size of a soccer ball can squeeze through a hole the size of a quarter!
questions.explanation: The main idea is describing the octopus's amazing abilities.

questions.text: What is 'camouflage'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Changing appearance to blend in

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains camouflage is when the octopus 'can change its color and texture' to hide.

questions.text: How many hearts does an octopus have?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Three

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says an octopus has 'three hearts.'

questions.text: Why can an octopus squeeze through tiny spaces?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: It has no bones

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains 'Because it has no bones, it can fit through any hole larger than its beak.'

questions.text: How does the author support the idea that octopuses are intelligent?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: By describing how they solve puzzles, open jars, and recognize different people

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author gives specific examples of intelligent behavior.

questions.text: Why did Sophie want to be a cat?

choices: She thought cats had easy lives
questionOptions.correctAnswer: She thought cats had easy lives

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Sophie wanted to be a cat. Cats got to sleep all day and play whenever they wanted. Her cat Whiskers wanted to be a girl. Girls got treats whenever they asked and could open doors themselves. One magical morning, they switched places! Sophie-the-cat tried to nap in the sunny spot. But the dog kept barking. The vacuum cleaner was terrifying. And she was so hungry, but she couldn't open the refrigerator. Whiskers-the-girl tried to get ice cream. But she had to do homework first. Then she had to clean her room. And everyone kept asking her questions she couldn't answer. By evening, they were both exhausted. "I miss being me," Sophie whispered. "Me too," Whiskers seemed to say. They touched noses, and—POOF—they were themselves again. "Being a cat looks easier than it is," Sophie said, scratching Whiskers's ears. They both agreed that their own life was just right.
questions.explanation: Sophie thought 'Cats got to sleep all day and play whenever they wanted.'

questions.text: What lesson does this story teach?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Appreciate your own life

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows that both learned their own lives were 'just right.'

questions.text: What problem did Sophie-the-cat have?

choices: She couldn't find the sunny spot
She couldn't open the refrigerator when hungry
questionOptions.correctAnswer: She couldn't open the refrigerator when hungry

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'she was so hungry, but she couldn't open the refrigerator.'

questions.text: How is the story organized?

choices: It tells what Sophie experienced, then what Whiskers experienced
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It tells what Sophie experienced, then what Whiskers experienced

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story describes both experiences separately to show parallel problems.

questions.text: How does the author show that both characters learned something?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: By having them both miss being themselves and agree their own life was just right
acceptableAnswers: they agree their life was right
both wanted to be themselves again

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Both characters realize their original life was better than they thought.

questions.text: What evidence supports the claim that plastic pollution hurts sea turtles?

choices: Turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and get sick
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and get sick

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Sea turtles have lived on Earth for over 100 million years—even longer than dinosaurs. But today, many species are in danger. People are working hard to save them. One big threat is plastic pollution. Sea turtles sometimes mistake plastic bags for jellyfish, their favorite food. Eating plastic can make them very sick. Many beaches now ban plastic bags to help. Another problem is that turtles nest on beaches that have been built up with hotels and houses. Bright lights from buildings confuse baby turtles. They crawl toward the lights instead of the ocean. Volunteers protect nests and turn off lights during nesting season. Climate change also affects sea turtles. The temperature of sand determines whether eggs become male or female turtles. Warmer temperatures mean more females are born. Scientists are studying how to help balance this. Everyone can help by reducing plastic use and supporting protected beaches.
questions.explanation: The text explains turtles 'mistake plastic bags for jellyfish' and 'eating plastic can make them very sick.'

questions.text: What causes baby turtles to crawl toward buildings instead of the ocean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Bright lights confuse them

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Bright lights from buildings confuse baby turtles.'

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: Sea turtles are in danger and people are working to save them
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Sea turtles are in danger and people are working to save them

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main idea is about threats to sea turtles and conservation efforts.

questions.text: What does the author want readers to do after reading this text?

choices: Help by reducing plastic use and supporting conservation
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Help by reducing plastic use and supporting conservation

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author ends with 'Everyone can help by reducing plastic use and supporting protected beaches.'

questions.text: How long have sea turtles lived on Earth?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Over 100 million years

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Sea turtles have lived on Earth for over 100 million years.'

questions.text: What could Marco NOT do well?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Juggle, dance, and do magic

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: "I can't do anything special," Marco told his sister Elena. The school talent show was next week, and everyone had an act except him. "What about juggling?" Elena asked. Marco tried. Oranges flew everywhere. "Dancing?" Marco stepped on his own feet. "Magic tricks?" The cards scattered across the floor. Marco felt hopeless. That night, he helped his dad make dinner. He chopped vegetables perfectly while telling jokes that made his dad laugh. "Marco," his dad said, "you have many talents. You're kind, funny, and a great helper. Not all talents belong on a stage." Marco thought about this. On talent show day, he volunteered to help backstage. He made nervous performers laugh. He found lost costumes. He cheered everyone on. After the show, the principal thanked him. "The show couldn't have happened without you," she said. Marco smiled. Helping others was his talent.
questions.explanation: The text shows Marco failing at juggling, dancing, and magic tricks.

questions.text: What is the message of this story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Everyone has different valuable talents

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story teaches that talents aren't just stage performances; helping others is a talent too.

questions.text: How did Marco change from the beginning to the end?

choices: He went from feeling hopeless to proud
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He went from feeling hopeless to proud

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Marco went from feeling 'hopeless' to smiling when recognized for his real talents.

questions.text: What does 'not all talents belong on a stage' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Valuable abilities aren't always performances

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Dad means that valuable abilities aren't just things you perform in front of others.

questions.text: How did the author show that helping is a talent?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: By showing how Marco helped backstage and the principal thanking him, saying the show couldn't have happened without him

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author demonstrates the value of helping through the principal's recognition.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: Pizza has a long history from ancient times to today
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Pizza has a long history from ancient times to today

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Pizza is one of the world's favorite foods, but where did it come from? Flatbreads with toppings have been eaten for thousands of years. Ancient Egyptians, Greeks, and Romans all ate similar foods. However, modern pizza came from Italy. In the 1800s, poor people in Naples, Italy, needed cheap, quick food. They put tomatoes, cheese, and other toppings on flatbread. In 1889, a baker named Raffaele Esposito made a special pizza for Queen Margherita of Italy. He used tomatoes, mozzarella cheese, and basil—red, white, and green like the Italian flag. The queen loved it! This pizza is still called Margherita pizza today. Italian immigrants brought pizza to America in the late 1800s. The first American pizzeria opened in New York City in 1905. After World War II, pizza became popular across America. Soldiers who had been to Italy wanted pizza when they came home. Today, about 5 billion pizzas are sold around the world every year!
questions.explanation: The main idea traces pizza's history from ancient times to the present.

questions.text: How is this text organized?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: In time order (chronological)

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text follows pizza's history in order from ancient times to today.

questions.text: Why did poor people in Naples eat pizza?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: It was cheap and quick

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'poor people in Naples, Italy, needed cheap, quick food.'

questions.text: What helped pizza become popular in America after World War II?

choices: Soldiers who had eaten pizza in Italy
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Soldiers who had eaten pizza in Italy

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Soldiers who had been to Italy wanted pizza when they came home.'

questions.text: Why did Esposito choose red, white, and green toppings for the Queen's pizza?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: To match the colors of the Italian flag

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says he 'used tomatoes, mozzarella cheese, and basil—red, white, and green like the Italian flag.'
